Award.AwardTitle: Probing metal catalyst-support interactions using small cluster models: Gas-phase reactivity studies, anion photoelectron spectroscopy, and DFT calculations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program supports the efforts of Professor Caroline C. Jarrold from Indiana University to study the interplay between electronic and structural properties of well-defined cluster models used to study the inherently local phenomenon of catalyst-support and catalyst-support-substrate interactions. A three-pronged approach is used to characterize cluster models of new catalysts that have been identified as particularly active toward the industrially-important water-gas shift reaction. (The water gas shift reaction catalytically combines water and carbon monoxide to produce dihydrogen and carbon dioxide.) Anion photoelectron (PE) spectroscopy measurements on model clusters provide a mass-specific electronic profile of the clusters as a function of both metal composition and oxygen content. Cluster structures are determined by reconciling experimental PE spectra with computational results and gas-phase reactivity studies on the clusters allow for the correlation between cluster reactivity and cluster molecular and electronic structures. The first series of studies focus on platinum-containing cluster systems inspired by recent literature. Alternative and less expensive cluster models rationalized to have similar (and possibly improved) attributes are also explored and compared to known industrial catalysts. The broader impacts of these studies include the generation of knowledge that can inform the design of improved, lower-cost and more energy-efficient catalysts for water gas shift reactions and the evaluation of new computational approaches used to study metal oxides in non-traditional oxidation states. In addition, a new generation of scientists are trained to understand industrially-relevant catalysis reactions.

Metal oxides are often used as industrial catalysts. Their composition is often optimized so that the catalysts operate at lower temperatures or with cheaper and more readily available materials. This research project is designed to determine the essential molecular-scale features that govern catalysts used in the water gas shift reaction. The water gas shift reaction combines water and carbon monoxide to make dihydrogen and carbon dioxide. Experimental and computational tools are used to create and study the properties of well-defined nano- and sub-nanometer scale bits of metal oxides used in this industrially important reaction. The technical broader implications of this project include a reduced energy consumption for this industrial process. A more immediate and direct outcome of this project is the training of young women and men in the scientific method using computational and experimental platforms centered on a project that motivated by practical industrial concerns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Catalysts are materials or molecules that increase the rates of chemical reactions.  The importance of catalysts in industry and the economy cannot be overstated, and research on improving or designing new catalytic materials is prolific.  Historically, studies of molecules interacting with highly-ordered metal or metal oxide surfaces have been used to characterize catalyst-reactant molecule interactions.  However, these important interactions are inherently on the scale of a molecule, and the catalyst itself undergoes numerous processes accompanying the chemical change of the reactant molecule.  There is a large body of evidence that points to defect sites such as oxygen vacancies on metal oxides surfaces, and molecular-scale interactions between the catalyst and material that is supporting the catalysts can enhance (or diminish) activity. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the use of cluster models as an alternative approach for the study of the local phenomenon of catalyst-support and catalyst-support-reactant molecule interactions.  Clusters are tiny fragments of matter that can assume the properties of small defect sites on catalyst.   In particular, our focus on heteronuclear suboxide (metal centers with more electrons than in the bulk metal oxide) cluster systems has elucidated the uniquely complex electronic environments that suggest specific mechanisms for activity enhancement in several types of real catalyst systems (e.g., MoxWx¢Oy; Al[MOy], M = Mo, W; Ptn/CexOy).

As one example, platinum metal is a well-known but very expensive catalyst.  Recent studies reported in the literature [A. Bruix, J.A. Rodriguez, P.J. Ramirez, S.D. Senanayake, J. Evans, J.B. Park, D. Stacchiola, P. Liu, J. Hrbek, and F. Illas, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 134, 8968-8974 (2012)] showed that the effectiveness of platinum in catalyzing the “water-gas shift reaction,” an important reaction for hydrogen production and purification, could be increased simply by using a fairly common material, ceria, as a support material for small particles of platinum.  We studied the electronic properties of small platinum-ceria clusters with both experiments and theoretical calculations, and found that the specific properties of both platinum and ceria allowed for the platinum to accumulate more electrons needed to catalyze this hydrogen producing reaction.  We went a step further to find that if another element is added to the ceria (samarium), the activity of the platinum/ceria catalyst/support combination may be further improved. Research conducted under this grant has resulted in twelve published papers, with two additional manuscripts in preparation.

In terms of broader impacts, this project, the goal of which was to inform efforts to design and optimize heterogeneous catalysts, has been the central focus in the education and cultivation of undergraduate students, graduate students, and a postdoctoral research associate. My research group is inclusive of women and minorities, and has trained students in the areas of physical and inorganic chemistry, spectroscopy, computational chemistry, and general gas-phase physical chemistry laboratory techniques (lasers, vacuum technology, molecular beams, electronics, plumbing, computer interfacing, etc.). At the end of their graduate training, they are scientists who can solve problems with a very practical “Jack of all trades” skill set. Former participants in this project are currently all employed as postdoctoral research associates or at companies that specialize in scientific instrumentation production.  Furthermore, all participants in this project have been active in outreach to the community.  Among the group’s activities have been regular visits to one of the local elementary schools to discuss what it is like to be a scientist with the students, frequent outreach events at the local children’s museum (Wonderlab) and with a local Girl Scout troop.  We hope to continue to inspire the next generation of scientists with these outreach efforts.
